Description: Black hematite cylinder seal; the robed king with an animal offering faces an ascending sun god who holds a ring and rests his foot on a rectangular, panelled mountain beneath a star-disc and crescent. In the space left for an inscription were later added, by a less competent craftsmen, a two-strand vertical guilloche, a smiting weather god in ascending posture on the back of a bull whose leash he holds together with a lightning fork; there is no trace of a weapon in his raised left hand. There is a base-line beneath the scene excluding the guilloche; upper edge chipped.
Bibliographic references: Collon 1986a / Catalogue of the Western Asiatic Seals in the British Museum: Cylinder Seals III: Isin-Larsa and Old Babylonian Periods (458)
Leichty E et al 1988a / Catalogue of the Babylonian Tablets in the British Museum, volume VIII: Tablets from Sippar 3 (p.300)
Acquisition name: From: Sir Ernest A T Wallis Budge
